{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3561123,"name":"Tharun","username":"thaMan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e5b9ba/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T21:32:00.287Z","cooked":"

Hey guys im the programming head for team 8816 and I had a quick question on something I stumbled upon in the MAX Swerve Template Code. Basically I noticed that for both PID controllers (this being both turning and driving) both values have Feed Forwards but my confusion stems from the fact that the variable is used no where and even if I wanted to use it I would also have to tune further variables like kV and kA as well. Me and my team have been wanting to add a feedforward and so we were wondering if there would be any way to easily implement the feedforward using the variables we were given or if we would have to re work the template to use both the PID and feedforward.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T21:32:00.287Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":24,"reads":45,"readers_count":44,"score":129.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496127,"topic_slug":"feedforward-in-max-swerve-template-code","display_username":"Tharun","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57591,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/feedforward-in-max-swerve-template-code/496127/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3561139,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T21:48:30.004Z","cooked":"

We tuned feedforwards last year for driving but haven’t this year with new configs.

Last year we had to add the feedforwards to setReference and tune it with kS, kV, kA. Which mostly we logged the wheel velocities and setpoints and used advantage scope to adjust so that the velocity were the same between wheels to the setpoints, and there wasn’t too much overshoot (lowering kA).

    var sign = Math.signum(optimizedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond);
    m_drivingPIDController.setReference(optimizedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond, 
                                        CANSparkMax.ControlType.kVelocity,
                                        0,
                                        m_feedforward.calculate(
                                          sign*m_desiredState.speedMetersPerSecond,
                                          sign*desiredState.speedMetersPerSecond,
                                          0.02)
                                        );
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T21:58:00.785Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":38,"readers_count":37,"score":12.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496127,"topic_slug":"feedforward-in-max-swerve-template-code","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/feedforward-in-max-swerve-template-code/496127/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3561205,"name":"Martin Nemaric","username":"Martini159","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T22:35:31.969Z","cooked":"

Line 31 below uses a feedforward calculation (basically 1 / maximum speed) as part of the closedLoop config.

github.com

REVrobotics/MAXSwerve-Java-Template/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/Configs.java#L31


      
    
          
  1. drivingConfig
    2. 
          
  2.         .idleMode(IdleMode.kBrake)
    3. 
          
  3.         .smartCurrentLimit(50);
    4. 
          
  4. drivingConfig.encoder
    5. 
          
  5.         .positionConversionFactor(drivingFactor) // meters
    6. 
          
  6.         .velocityConversionFactor(drivingFactor / 60.0); // meters per second
    7. 
          
  7. drivingConfig.closedLoop
    8. 
          
  8.         .feedbackSensor(FeedbackSensor.kPrimaryEncoder)
    9. 
          
  9.         // These are example gains you may need to them for your own robot!
    10. 
          
  10.         .pid(0.04, 0, 0)
    11. 
          
  11.         .velocityFF(drivingVelocityFeedForward)
    12. 
          
  12.         .outputRange(-1, 1);
    13. 
          
  13. 
          
  14. turningConfig
    15. 
          
  15.         .idleMode(IdleMode.kBrake)
    16. 
          
  16.         .smartCurrentLimit(20);
    17. 
          
  17. turningConfig.absoluteEncoder
    18. 
          
  18.         // Invert the turning encoder, since the output shaft rotates in the opposite
    19. 
          
  19.         // direction of the steering motor in the MAXSwerve Module.
    20. 
          
  20.         .inverted(true)
    21. 
          
  21.         .positionConversionFactor(turningFactor) // radians
    22.

The REVLib API docs note that this the “velocity feedforward gain of the controller”

codedocs.revrobotics.com

ClosedLoopConfig (FRC-REVLib API)

declaration: package: com.revrobotics.spark.config, class: ClosedLoopConfig

I am under the impression that the arbitrary feedforward calculation is basically obfuscated in line 104 here. It simply takes the commanded velocity and multiplies it by the “velocity feedforward gain”

github.com

REVrobotics/MAXSwerve-Java-Template/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/MAXSwerveModule.java#L104


      
    
          
  1.   public void setDesiredState(SwerveModuleState desiredState) {
    2. 
          
  2.     // Apply chassis angular offset to the desired state.
    3. 
          
  3.     SwerveModuleState correctedDesiredState = new SwerveModuleState();
    4. 
          
  4.     correctedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond = desiredState.speedMetersPerSecond;
    5. 
          
  5.     correctedDesiredState.angle = desiredState.angle.plus(Rotation2d.fromRadians(m_chassisAngularOffset));
    6. 
          
  6. 
          
  7.     // Optimize the reference state to avoid spinning further than 90 degrees.
    8. 
          
  8.     correctedDesiredState.optimize(new Rotation2d(m_turningEncoder.getPosition()));
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10.     // Command driving and turning SPARKS towards their respective setpoints.
    11. 
          
  11.     m_drivingClosedLoopController.setReference(correctedDesiredState.speedMetersPerSecond, ControlType.kVelocity);
    12. 
          
  12.     m_turningClosedLoopController.setReference(correctedDesiredState.angle.getRadians(), ControlType.kPosition);
    13. 
          
  13. 
          
  14.     m_desiredState = desiredState;
    15. 
          
  15.   }
    16. 
          
  16. 
          
  17.   /** Zeroes all the SwerveModule encoders. */
    18. 
          
  18.   public void resetEncoders() {
    19. 
          
  19.     m_drivingEncoder.setPosition(0);
    20. 
          
  20.   }
    21. 
          
  21. }
    22.

TL;DR A velocity feedforward is being used, but there are no static or acceleration components.

That is correct. You’d want to zero out the other feedforward if you are adding your own.
